repnme.cdata!:
Nepal - Second Rural Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project (RWSSP)

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Rural Water
            Supply and Sanitation Project (RWSSP) for Nepal were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was low or negligible, Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned include: the demand-driven community
            based model implemented by the Fund Board was able to
            withstand the implementation challenges of operating in a
            conflict environment. The RWSSP II, was able not only to
            address the implementation issues which affected the first
            project, but also to experiment and pilot innovations. These
            innovations allowed the RWSS program to grow and evolve, and
            could not have been introduced under the first project,
            which focused on developing the foundations of the Fund
            Boards delivery model. The project had a remarkable gender
            impact by freeing women and girls of the time previously
            spent fetching water to distant locations. The Fund Board
            would need to reorient to address the emerging trends of
            growing demand for improved service levels in rural areas
            development phase of the Fund Boards delivery model, during
            which communities are mobilized, and community decisions are
            made, is a unique feature and an important investment that
            assures ownership, successful implementation, and
            sustainability of the schemes.

repnme.cdata!:
Nepal - Second Rural Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Second Rural Water
            Supply and Sanitation Project for Nepal is to undertake land
            policy and institutional reforms and key land administration
            pilots for laying the foundation for sustainable
            decentralized land administration system that is fair,
            efficient, and cost effective and ensures land tenure
            security. There is a need to reallocate eligible
            expenditures between the different categories under the
            original project. This has been caused by increase in unit
            costs, implementing more schemes serving a larger population
            than originally planned at preparation, thereby scope of
            works being more than originally anticipated in the schemes.
            The closing date of the project extended from the current
            December 31, 2010 to August 30, 2011. This will allow
            additional schemes to be completed and increase the number
            of beneficiary households, while scaling up innovative
            initiatives such as scheme insurance, social accountability
            and improving income generating activities, particularly of
            women. This will be the second extension of the closing
            date, representing a cumulative extension of just less than
            two years.

display_title.display_title:
Nepal - Second Rural Water Supply
            and Sanitation Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet
